Burford believes that yesterday’s share price movement relates to a rumour of a potential “short attack” or “bear raid”, a tactic where short sellers take on a short position in a company’s stock and then engage in claims about the company in an effort to alarm investors, depress a company’s stock and profit from the decline. Burford also believes that some of its prior recent share price volatility is related to such activity.
There is a clear line between appropriate commentary and market manipulation, and Burford is investigating, with the assistance of market experts and experienced outside litigation counsel, the market activities here and will take appropriate legal action should we discover actionable misconduct. We are strongly suspicious that yesterday’s significant fall in the share price was based on such actionable misconduct.
Short sellers of this ilk are not long-term investors. Rather, their goal is to panic investors into selling their holdings and thereby to drive down the share price. If investors oblige them, then the attack succeeds, long-term investors are harmed and the short sellers pocket a quick payday.

Over the past year, we have argued that Sirius Minerals represents an
attractive risk/reward play. With Tuesday’s news that the company has
been forced to delay the offering of its USD500m bond, we believe the risks
relating to the project are now greater than the reward. As such, we
recommend that potential investors wait until certainty is achieved on the
USD500m bond offering. We downgrade Sirius Minerals to Hold and lower
our price target to GBp17.
● USD500m high-yield bond offer delayed: Sirius Minerals announced
earlier this week that it is suspending the proposed USD500m bond
offering which was part of the initial financing package outlined in May.
The company cited a worsening of market conditions for this delay. The
USD500m offering was a key component of the financing package, given
that completion gives Sirius Minerals access to the USD2.5bn revolving
credit facility (RCF) that underpins its Woodsmith project. The RCF was
intended to have a seven-year tenor with every USD500m potentially
releasing another USD300m of liquidity.
● Risk now too high: Under the terms of the RCF, the company has to
complete the high-yield bond offering by the end of September otherwise
it cannot draw down on the funds. As outlined in the financing package,
there is no guarantee that alternative methods of financing can be secured
(in the event the high-yield bond and RCF are not completed), and as such
the company could again run into cash flow issues. With the deadline for
completion now drawing closer, the risk is now too high to argue that
Sirius Minerals’ shares currently represent an attractive investment.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

View unchanged on long-term project economics: Should Sirius secure
financing for its Woodsmith site, we think the project economics look
favourable. Taking conservative assumptions on pricing, volumes and
capex, the project should generate an IRR of 15% at a P/NPV ratio of 0.4x.
The mine also has the potential to operate at EBITDA margins in excess of
50% given the relatively low amount of operating expenditure required to
run the mine. We incorporate a completion risk factor of 50% in our
company valuation, and lower our price target to GBp17 as a result.
● Polyhalite has its merits: We remain positive about the credentials of
polyhalite as a multi-nutrient fertiliser when it comes to market post-2020.
In our view, Sirius Minerals’ product POLY4 can adequately compete as a
speciality fertiliser product on the market given it can offer a cheaper and
